isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - DUAL STEERING SYSTEM - INTEGRAL SLAVE GEAR

svcsubproc.title: M-Series
svcsubproc.para: The major components in the slave gear are the power piston and the sector shaft assembly ( Figure 105).

figure.caption: Figure 106. Power Piston and Sector Shaft Assembly

svcsubproc.para: Slave gear disassembly requires removal of cylinder heads and the sector shaft cover.
The sector shaft assembly is removed and the piston is pulled out of the housing bore.
The sector shaft bearings and the various seals are serviced using the same procedures as the master gear.
On reassembly, the timing marks on the piston rack and the sector shaft must be carefully timed.
The M-Series models use a seal ring on one end of the power piston. A new seal is installed by placing the back-up O-ring in the piston groove and installing the teflon seal ring over it.

note.para: The seal material will stretch as it is fitted to the ring groove. If you let the piston set with the seal rings in place, it will become easier to install it in the piston bore. Use of a ring compressor is best to limit damage to the piston ring ( Figure 106).

figure.caption: Figure 107. Fit Seal to Ring Groove

note.para: The housing will have a beveled chamfer on one end of the piston housing. The piston is installed through that end of the housing. Light taps with a soft hammer may be required on the end of the piston to move it into the housing.

svcsubproc.para: To re-install piston, carefully work the piston ring past the pinion gear opening in the cylinder bore. While maintaining pressure on the end of the piston, press the piston seal into the ring groove. As the piston ring is compressed into the ring groove, the piston will slide further into the bore until the piston ring has passed through the pinion gear opening ( Figure 107).

figure.caption: Figure 108. Press Piston Seal into Ring Groove

svcsubproc.title: 92 Series
svcsubproc.para: The major components in the slave gear are the power piston and the pinion gear/sector shaft assembly.
Disassembly of the slave gear requires the removal of the cylinder heads and the pinion cover/mounting bracket.
The sector shaft assembly is removed and the piston is pulled out of the housing bore.
Refer to Figure 108 for all Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Remove pitman arm retainer (Item 6) and pitman arm (Item 5) from the output shaft.
Remove the socket head capscrews (Item 4) that hold the retainer plate (Item 3) in place.
Remove the retainer plate, clean and save for reassembly.
Remove oil seal (Item 2) and snap ring (Item 1) from bore and discard.

Lubricate the O.D. and I.D. of seal assembly (Item 7) with chassis lube. Wrap the splined end of the shaft with greased paper and slide the seal into place over the shaft. Carefully tap seal assembly into housing bore until it is flush with face of housing.
Install plate (Item 3) and hex head capscrews (Item 8) as shown in Figure 108. Tighten the capscrews to 10 to 14 ft-lbs. (13.8 to 19.4 Nm).
Install pitman arm (Item 5) by aligning timing mark on pitman arm with the timing mark on the output shaft.

Install pitman arm retainer (Item 6). Apply Never-Seize between the pitman arm and retainer in the threads of the output shaft and on the threads of the retainer. Tighten the retainer to 225 ft-lbs. (305 Nm) for 292 and 392, and to 450 ft-lbs. (610 Nm) for 492 Series.

svcsubproc.para: On reassembly, the timing marks on the piston rack and the sector shaft must be carefully timed using the same procedure as the Master Gear ( Figure 109).

figure.caption: Figure 110. Timing Marks Must Be Carefully Timed

svcsubproc.para: 92 Series slave gear models use seal rings on the ends of the power piston.
New seals are installed by placing the back-up O-ring in the piston groove and installing the teflon seal ring over it ( Figure 110).

note.para: Seal material will stretch as it is fitted to the ring groove. If you let the piston set with the seal rings in place, it will become easier to install it in the piston bore. Use of a ring compressor is best to limit damage to the piston ring ( Figure 111).

figure.caption: Figure 112. Fit Seal to Ring Groove

note.para: The housing will have a beveled chamfer on one end of the piston housing. The piston is installed through that end of the housing. Light taps with a soft hammer may be required on the end of the piston to move it into the housing ( Figure 112).

figure.caption: Figure 113. Install Piston Through End of Housing

svcsubproc.para: You will have to work the piston ring past the pinion gear opening in the cylinder bore carefully. While maintaining pressure on the end of the piston, press the piston seal into the ring groove. As the piston ring is compressed into the ring groove, the piston will slide further into the bore until the piston ring has passed the pinion gear opening ( Figure 113).

figure.caption: Figure 114. Work Piston Ring Past Pinion Gear Opening
